I'm all for that, but that requires nice and mean and even our debates. I like this. This is my favorite. This is one of my favorite dualities here. This is great. Well, thank you very much. I don't get to do this every time, most of the time, they're all you. You know, polite, you know that's not where it's at. For sure. Make people think for sure. People question, make people ask questions and stir it up and get them in debate. You get there's more views there?

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: Evil doesn't exist objectively - it's a perception based on incomplete awareness. What we label 'evil' is simply an event we haven't yet seen the benefits of.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: Every event has both upsides and downsides - the unity of opposites. To see only one side is to have incomplete awareness.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: Morality evolves from amygdala-driven absolutism (primitive) to prefrontal cortex relativism (advanced). The highest moral reasoning sees events objectively without labels.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: Therapeutic dissolution - helping people find the 'other side' of traumatic events - frees them from victimhood. Making things good/bad keeps people trapped as victims.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: Morality is culturally relative - what's considered evil in one society is acceptable in another. There are no universally ascended moral values across time and space.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: Our job is to discover the hidden order in apparent chaos, not to judge events as good or evil. When we discover this order, we're graced.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: Labeling something evil prevents understanding why it happened. To understand is not to condone - it's to see the full picture and potentially prevent future harm.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: The person doing harm believes they're doing good within their value system. No one does anything unless they believe it gives them more advantage than disadvantage.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: Even Jesus wasn't one-sided. The texts show him neither entirely good nor bad - these are labels we project based on our allegiances.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: Anthropomorphizing good and evil as God and devil is projection. Divinity includes everything - it's not local to a particular culture or time.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: Life and death are paired - neither is inherently good or bad. Your body has build and destroy in perfect balance. Bringing some people into life is their torture.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: Beyond the outer appearance, there's nothing but love. All else is illusion. The quality of your life depends on the quality of questions you ask.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: Whatever you perceive in the world around you is a reprojection of yourself. Predators appear to make us realize parts of ourselves we haven't owned.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: Most people are unconscious automatons. They react, then 200 milliseconds later construct a reason why. True conscious awareness is rare.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: Some things ARE fundamentally wrong - child abuse, torture, assault. This isn't perspective; it's embodied knowledge we 'know in our body.'

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: There is something fundamental inside us driving toward life, love, freedom. If someone intentionally interferes with that, we have an obligation to stop them.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: We have an obligation - an 'ought' - to act against evil. This isn't just preference; it's sacred duty.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: Morality has evolved - the Zoroastrians stopping child sacrifice is clear moral progress. We shouldn't regress to 'whatever culture thinks is fine.'

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: There's a middle path between absolutism and relativism. Situation plays a part, but some things remain fundamentally wrong across all contexts.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: We participate in God, not just observe. We are co-creators, not passive witnesses to cosmic events.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: Evil is a 'cosmic conspiracy to separate us from love.' There are actual forces working against unity and connection.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: Life itself is good. God desires ever-deepening complexity of thought, more life, more love, more beauty.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: Intentional, prolonged torture of innocents (like a child) for pleasure is absolutely evil. No situational context can justify it.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: The fact that we have laws against these things, that 80% of people would be horrified by these images, shows values are anthropologically embedded in us.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: Ho'oponopono teaches us to locate in ourselves what we find reprehensible in others. This is healing work, but it doesn't negate that some acts are truly harmful.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: Yeshua said 'forgive them for they know not what they do' - beautiful teaching. But this addresses ignorance, not intentional evil.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: I can appreciate the therapeutic value of finding meaning in tragedy while still believing some acts are fundamentally wrong.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: Rumi is NOT the same as a jihadist. There's a fundamental difference between promoting love and promoting violence.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: Rumi is, in his own way, a jihadist - promoting his ideal. Both are trying to do what they think is God's will.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: I don't go to forgiveness - I go all the way to gratitude. Forgiveness assumes something needed forgiving. True healing is 'thank you.'

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: You react in proportion to your morality at the time. If you see something as evil, you'll try to stop it - but it's evil in YOUR perception.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: There are upsides to the murder of children. The Oklahoma City bombing mother said it was 'one of the greatest things that ever happened' to her.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: To say life is good and death is bad is very narrow. Evolution requires extinctions. Your body requires cellular death.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: When you make evil 'out there' and good 'out there,' you dissociate from yourself. It's all you - there are no good and bad people, just people.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: The murdered child doesn't get a chance to be grateful. The family may find meaning, but the child's life was taken.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: If I see someone putting a cat in a microwave, I'm going to stop it - not because of trauma but because value lives inside me. It's intrinsic to the cosmos.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: I came expecting a conversation about thoughts impacting reality. Instead we found a bright point of distinction. Debate is healthy when people stand by their opinions.

claim_landmarks.speaker: marcus
claim_landmarks.text: Is there such a thing as good and evil, or is it all one source without distinction? I believe it's a bit of both.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: I'm teaching people to be masters of their destiny, not victims of history. Finding blessings in trauma sets people free.

claim_landmarks.speaker: demartini
claim_landmarks.text: I'm not going to pacify my research for any human being on this planet. The reality is there's upsides to every event.
